title: 111_hr6195
content: The Act titled "Ensuring Justice Along the Southwest Border Act of 2010" provides for additional judgeships in certain judicial districts. The President appoints additional district judges in various districts, including Arizona, California, New Mexico, and Texas. The Act "Ensuring Justice Along the Southwest Border Act of 2010" provides for these new judgeships. The Act authorizes additional district judgeships in Arizona, California, New Mexico, and Texas. The President appoints new judges for specific districts as outlined in the Act. The Act authorizes additional district judgeships in Arizona, California, New Mexico, and Texas. The first vacancy in the office of district judge in each judicial district appointed under the Act, occurring 10 years or more after enactment, shall not be filled. The table in title 28, United States Code, is amended to reflect changes in the total number of permanent district judgeships authorized. The Act authorizes additional district judgeships in Arizona, California, New Mexico, and Texas. Arizona has 14 judgeships, California has 18 in the Northern region, 10 in the Eastern region, 31 in the Central region, and 13 in the Southern region. New Mexico has 8 judgeships. Texas has a revised number of judgeships. Texas has a revised number of judgeships in different regions: Northern (12), Southern (21), Eastern (9), and Western (17). Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of this section. Additionally, there is a program for Special Assistant United States Attorneys. The Attorney General will allocate funds for hiring and training special assistant United States attorneys to prosecute border-related offenses. This includes training local prosecutors in relevant laws, cross-designating them as special assistants, and hiring additional prosecutors for both Federal and State cases. The Attorney General will allocate funds for hiring and training special assistant United States attorneys to prosecute border-related offenses, with the highest priority given to cases where charges are submitted for consideration and the defendant has a previous conviction for a border-related offense. Appropriations are authorized for the implementation of this section, defining "border-related offense" as specific violations under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The specified offenses under various sections of title 18, United States Code, and the Controlled Substances Act are considered border-related offenses for prosecution by special assistant United States attorneys.
